headline.main: SATELITE LINKED TO SPACE STATION AS RUSSIANS AIM FOR LARGER CRAFT

results.snippet: In an important test of the Soviet Union's ability to assemble larger space stations, a satellite was linked yesterday to the unoccupied, Earth-orbiting Salyut 7 and all systems were reported to be functioning normally, the official Soviet press...
results.lead_paragraph: In an important test of the Soviet Union's ability to assemble larger space stations, a satellite was linked yesterday to the unoccupied, Earth-orbiting Salyut 7 and all systems were reported to be functioning normally, the official Soviet press agency Tass announced. The maneuver was seen by American experts as a prelude to operations aboard the Salyut space station involving larger crews than before that would probably attempt to set new flight endurance records. A crew of perhaps three astronauts could be sent to the newly enlarged space station in the next few weeks in a Soyuz spacecraft.

results.snippet: A SERIES of pleasant surprises occurred recently in the life of Lewis Love, chairman of the science department at Great Neck South High School. First, he realized that the woman selected to be the first female astronaut, scheduled to go aloft in...
results.lead_paragraph: A SERIES of pleasant surprises occurred recently in the life of Lewis Love, chairman of the science department at Great Neck South High School. First, he realized that the woman selected to be the first female astronaut, scheduled to go aloft in the next United States space trip, was Mary Cleave, a student of his in the early 60's. Next he learned that Miss Cleave named him as one of the teachers who had most influenced her. Then he was told that Dave Marash of WNBC-TV News, while talking to the most recently selected astronauts, had been struck by the fact that each was a product of a highly rated public high school. They were Stuyvesant in Manhattan, Scarsdale in Westchester County and Great Neck High Schools. ''I told Dave Marash,'' Mr. Love said, ''that I remember Miss Cleave as a very hard-working young lady at a time when not many girls took physics. Don't forget, we not only didn't have computers then, we didn't even have calculators.''

results.snippet: Writing about China the other day, we innocently repeated what turns out to be an old savant's tale - that the Great Wall is the only mortal structure visible from the moon.   Challenged by a sharp-eyed reader (see Letters), we decided to check...
results.lead_paragraph: Writing about China the other day, we innocently repeated what turns out to be an old savant's tale - that the Great Wall is the only mortal structure visible from the moon. Challenged by a sharp-eyed reader (see Letters), we decided to check with higher authority, the Apollo astronaut Buzz Aldrin.

results.snippet: It's spring again in Washington - some things do run on time here. You can tell, for the star magnolia tree at the northwest gate of the White House is blooming once more, and the Gridiron Club is tuning up for its annual spoof of the resident...
results.lead_paragraph: It's spring again in Washington - some things do run on time here. You can tell, for the star magnolia tree at the northwest gate of the White House is blooming once more, and the Gridiron Club is tuning up for its annual spoof of the resident politicians. So, while Secretary of Defense Weinberger is proposing to spend $2 trillion or $3 trillion to save the Republic in the next few years and the President is trying to put over on the press his version of the Alien and Sedition Acts, the reporters of the Gridiron Club are taking their revenge in an evening of fun. And this year Washington is talking frivolously about a personal political question.

results.snippet: Senator John Glenn will declare his candidacy for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination April 21 in his hometown of New Concord, Ohio, his campaign office said today. The former astronaut already has a large campaign staff operating here.
results.lead_paragraph: Senator John Glenn will declare his candidacy for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination April 21 in his hometown of New Concord, Ohio, his campaign office said today. The former astronaut already has a large campaign staff operating here.

headline.main: REPUBLICAN IS FAVORED FOR HOUSE SEAT OF ASTRONAUT WHO DIED

results.snippet: In January, a week before he was to be sworn in as the first Representative from Colorado's new Sixth Congressional District, Jack Swigert, the former astronaut, died of cancer.   Next week a special election will be held in the suburban Denver...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In January, a week before he was to be sworn in as the first Representative from Colorado's new Sixth Congressional District, Jack Swigert, the former astronaut, died of cancer. Next week a special election will be held in the suburban Denver district to fill the Congressional seat left vacant by the death of Mr. Swigert, who handily won election Nov. 2 as a Republican. The voting March 29 will match Steve Hogan, the 34-year-old Democrat who was soundly defeated by Mr. Swigert last fall, against State Senator Daniel L. Schaefer, the Republican choice. Mr. Schaefer, whose campaign so far has raised nearly four times as much money as his opponent's, is regarded as the favorite to win in a suburban district in which Republicans outnumber Democrats.

headline.main: MUSEUM UNVIELS THE MYSTERY OF TIME

results.snippet: ''What is time?'' a museum staff member asked the fourth graders gathered around him. ''A clock,'' said one. ''A watch,'' said another. ''A round thing that moves,'' said a third. ''Time goes backward,'' a boy ventured.
results.lead_paragraph: ''What is time?'' a museum staff member asked the fourth graders gathered around him. ''A clock,'' said one. ''A watch,'' said another. ''A round thing that moves,'' said a third. ''Time goes backward,'' a boy ventured.

results.snippet: Gridiron Excerpts   Following are excerpts of songs sung Saturday at the 98th annual dinner of the Gridiron Club, the Washington newspaper organization famous for its annual roast of Government officials, and speeches in response by Senators John...
results.lead_paragraph: Gridiron Excerpts Following are excerpts of songs sung Saturday at the 98th annual dinner of the Gridiron Club, the Washington newspaper organization famous for its annual roast of Government officials, and speeches in response by Senators John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, and Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas. Among those attending was President Reagan, who, wearing a Mexican sombrero and sarape, took to the stage to join a chorus of '@'@M@a@ n@a@n@a@.@'@' Tune: ''March from Aida'' Sung by: the Press. All hail, we are the Fourth Estate, We are the truth and light, Often even right In the news that we choose to relate. The press, guiding the ship of state, Telling you where to steer, Hindsight crystal clear, Far and near, never fear, we are here.

headline.main: Republican is Elected To Succeed Jack Swigert

results.snippet: State Senator Dan Schaefer, a Republican, inheriting political support from the late Jack Swigert, easily defeated his Democratic opponent today to capture the Congressional seat left vacant by the death of the former astronaut.   With all 386...
results.lead_paragraph: State Senator Dan Schaefer, a Republican, inheriting political support from the late Jack Swigert, easily defeated his Democratic opponent today to capture the Congressional seat left vacant by the death of the former astronaut. With all 386 precincts Mr. Schaefer had 49,216 votes to 27,672 for Jack Hogan, a Democrat who is a member of the Aurora City Council.
